audio_caption: The clip begins with an upbeat Bollywood song setting an energetic mood, featuring prominent instrumentation. A male speaker interrupts the music. His voice is somewhat upbeat as he shares some facts about an actress, saying she's made "14 films in five different languages". There's a small clearing sound, like someone adjusting glasses. The speaker goes on to describe that this actress is a reality star, "TikTok famous", and has "50 TV commercials". He mentions her acting alongside stars like "Salman Khan". The music stops and the speaker confirms that the actress in question is "Sana Khan".  He mentions that she recently announced her intention to give up her career "to pursue her relationship with her creator".

The clip begins with a male speaker, using a welcoming and enthusiastic tone, introducing a special and beneficial episode. He then states the title, "My Tai ad of smile to Jannah." A female speaker follows, encouraging viewers to pray regularly and on time, in order to achieve its blessings. Next, a whooshing sound effect creates a transition. A male speaker says, "I think I'm a bit overacting there," spoken in a slightly exaggerated tone. The audio clip ends with a 'popping' sound.

The clip begins with a male speaker who, in a serious and deliberate tone, states they're "not just going to look on the surface of this matter," and will instead "look hard," as Rafiki from Lion King asked. He emphasizes that certain ideas should be held close and will "shape our reality." A soft, ethereal musical backing plays.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing a verse of the Quran about turning towards Allah, suggesting that a person's life is depressed if they don't remember Allah. He uses this as a point to assess the apparent happiness of people on social media, questioning if their claims are genuine and not just an act. This is followed by a female voice advising not to follow what isn't true and to follow what is right.

The clip begins with a single male speaker using a metaphor. He compares spiritual wellbeing to a car that runs out of fuel, saying "it's like a car... the actual fuel... is not present." He transitions to the importance of remembering Allah, stating "remembrance of Allah is our fuel" and quotes "it is only in his remembrance do our hearts find satisfaction," spoken with an uplifting, affirmative tone. Background music, featuring plucked string instruments and an ethereal, religious quality, accompanies his speech, enhancing the spiritual tone.

A male speaker begins by explaining why someone chose a specific life path over another, touching on "glamor" and "glitz." This is followed by a sound effect of a cash register, after which the speaker notes the relatability of routines for comfort and idleness. He mentions psychologists saying that people over 25-30 often find it hard to change and are "stuck in their ways," and that he will be mentioning two ways a person can change beyond that age.

The audio begins with a male speaker explaining something, speaking in a matter-of-fact tone. He mentions "constant reaffirmations" and quotes self-help books that say "it's going to be a good day, I can do this, I will do this," then stating those things actually work. He continues talking about prayers as affirmations, citing "alhamdulillah," meaning all praise be to Allah, who has given us life after death, explaining that they constantly do this when leaving or entering the house. There is consistent background noise throughout.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing trauma, specifically how it can "change us completely." He mentions the "death of a loved one" and heartbreak as "two main types" of trauma. The speaker's tone is conversational and informative. A short burst of laughter follows his statement about heartbreak.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker mentioning Sana's breakup with her partner Melvin and describing it as very public. A female speaker then speaks in Hindi, expressing regret and calling herself foolish for associating with a donkey. The male speaker resumes, explaining that the breakup involved infidelity and physical abuse. A second female speaker shares that she has pictures of being hit, with bruises on her face, which she will post after the interview. The first male speaker says the second female speaker was mentally affected and started taking sleeping pills. The second female speaker then cautions against sleeping tablets, noting she had to stop, and found that reciting more and more prayers was more effective for falling asleep.

The clip begins with a male speaker noting someone had a connection with Islam before. A female speaker then describes how she got finalized for a program but was going for her holy pilgrimage to Mecca Medina during Ramadan, which she could not cancel. A male speaker comments on how she continued with her show biz lifestyle alongside her faith, possibly realizing that she shouldnâ€™t be in this fake industry and lifestyle. The female speaker describes how she knows the industry is fake and how people are living their own lives, with this statement being spoken in an inquisitive tone. The clip ends with a male speaker mentioning the importance of positive friends around her to guide her during tough times.

The audio clip presents a conversation involving a male interviewer and a female speaker. The woman describes how she was counselled for three hours each day and was unable to sleep despite taking pills. A man confirms that she has since emerged as a stronger woman and began helping others after her relationship broke down in a bad way. The man then states that he respects that she spoke with her friends about her depression and is now in a position where she is speaking about these things from the heart. The woman then replies, stating "yes," and a distinct sound, resembling a chime, follows.

The audio clip features a female speaker emphasizing the importance of life, stating, "there is no matter in this world that is bigger than your life." Her tone is passionate and encouraging. Shortly after, she poses a question, "But if the life is gone, how are you going to correct it?" A brief sound effect then follows.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing an Instagram post, mentioning "questions about her purpose" and "the inevitable," namely "death," as points that cannot be answered by "any -ism and schism that we know," other than the creator. The speaker's tone is contemplative. There's no music or prominent background sounds, focusing attention on the speaker's monologue.

The clip starts with a man speaking in a somewhat conversational tone, reflecting on self-help books and feeling a lack of purpose. He speaks in the first person, mentioning a rapper, an actress, and a politician. He wonders about the meaning of life, asking "Why am I doing here?" and what happens after death. The clip concludes with a sound effect that may be a click or a short sound of agreement.

The clip starts with a male speaker pondering mortality, saying that there "is going to come a time where I'm just going to stop existing." He wonders about the feeling of non-existence, since he is "so used to existing." His tone is thoughtful and inquisitive. This speech is followed by an ambient electronic sound that is slightly unsettling.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, exhibiting an assertive and conversational tone, talking about "somebody who lives in London" and "success". He then shifts to expressing dissatisfaction with his current situation, mentioning "teaching kids multiplication, division, and spelling". He juxtaposes his life with that of "Sana Khan", emphasizing that "picking Islam over that lifestyle should say something".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker giving instructions and encouraging listeners to talk to Allah, expressing feelings of weakness and the need for help. He speaks with a sincere and reflective tone. A loud slap is abruptly heard.
